subject: Re: JUnit 3.5 & Ant 1.3
msgSnippet: There is a couple of other weird thing about the JUnit taskdef. a.) JUnit is included as part of the optional.jar from ant which is in my $ANT_HOME/lib
messageBody:
There is a couple of other weird thing about the JUnit taskdef.

a.) JUnit is included as part of the optional.jar from ant which is in
my $ANT_HOME/lib directory, yet I still have to provide the following
statement to get it to see the Junit Taskdef.

<taskdef name="junit"
classname="org.apache.tools.ant.taskdefs.optional.junit.JUnitTask" />

Maybe I misunderstood this, but I thought that taskdefs defined in the
optional jar did not need to be explicitly defined.

b.) Why is JUnit the only taskdef that I am having this problem with.


--- In junit@y..., Vitezslav Stejskal <vitezslav.stejskal@c...> wrote:
>
> There is a several things you have to keep in
> mind when using Ant:
>
> * all tasks are instantiated during the parsing time, even if they
will
> never be launched
>
> * tasks are loaded using the system classpath or the classpath
> defined in the taskdef element, this allows you to load
> task's class from the classpath defined in your script
>
> * the above rule has an exception - tasks placed in the
> package org.apache.tools.ant are *always* loaded using
> the system classpath
>
> Thus all built-in and optional tasks are loaded from the system
> classpath as well as any other class they need (in your case the
junit
> classes).
>
> So far I see two options:
> * put junit.jar on the system's claspath
> (modify CLASSPATH environment variable or put it into the
> ${ANT_HOME}/lib directory)
>
> * create new class derived from the
org.apache.tools.ant.taskdef.optional.junit.JUnitTask,
> place it in your own package and use the taskdef element to redefine
Ant's default
> junit task.
>
> Vita
